Measure: (1) same-session continuation rate (does the host do anything else before leaving?), (2) time-to-return for the next action (how long before the host comes back?), (3) next-phase engagement (does the host respond to the first proposal faster if they were in the forward-momentum group?).
elements.success_criteria: Variant A shows at least 20% higher same-session continuation rate. Time-to-return for the next action is at least 25% shorter for Variant A. Qualitative: hosts in Variant A describe the completion as 'I know what happens next' rather than 'I guess I am done now.'
elements.failure_meaning: If forward momentum copy does not increase continuation, the host may be genuinely done for the session (depleted after the wizard) and no copy can overcome that. In this case, the forward momentum is better invested in the re-engagement notification (behaves-006) rather than the completion screen. If time-to-return is similar, the preview may not be creating urgency or curiosity -- the next step may not be interesting enough to pull the host back.
elements.implementation_hint: Use feature flags for the completion screen variants. Track session_continued (any action after completion screen view within the same session) and next_action_timestamp (first action in the next session). The forward-momentum copy should reference the specific next step with a time estimate.

elements.title: Validate Depleted User Dignity: Invisible Smart Defaults
elements.problem: feels-007 asserts that smart defaults must be invisible accommodations, not labeled recommendations. The host should feel they are confirming research-based suggestions, not outsourcing their judgment. Highlighting that defaults are pre-filled diminishes the host's sense of agency.
elements.solution: Test whether different framings of default values affect the host's perceived ownership of their listing.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.insight: Depleted hosts CAN make good decisions but will not unless the cost is very low. Smart defaults make the cost near-zero while preserving dignity.
Andreas processes at full capacity early in the call but has less energy by the end. The platform must handle this transition gracefully.

elements.test_description: Show 6 hosts two versions of the pricing step (Step 4) with identical default values. Version A (invisible dignity): Fields pre-populated with 'Average for Washington Heights walk-ups: $2,400/mo' as the source label, no mention of 'recommended' or 'pre-filled.' Version B (highlighted recommendation): Banner at top: 'We have pre-filled your pricing based on similar listings. Review our suggestions below.' After completing each version, ask: 'Who decided the pricing for your listing -- you or the platform?' (open-ended) and 'How much ownership do you feel over your listing?' (1-5 scale).
elements.success_criteria: In Version A, at least 4 of 6 hosts describe the pricing decision as their own ('I decided' or 'I confirmed'). In Version B, at least 3 of 6 attribute the decision to the platform ('they suggested' or 'it was pre-filled'). Ownership rating for Version A is at least 0.7 points higher than Version B on the 5-point scale.
elements.failure_meaning: If both versions produce similar ownership feelings, the framing difference may be too subtle to affect perception -- hosts may not care whether defaults are labeled as recommendations or data. If Version B produces higher ownership (because it makes the defaults visible for review), transparency may be more important than invisibility for this audience.
elements.implementation_hint: Build two interactive prototypes of Step 4 with identical default values and identical modification affordances. The only difference is the framing copy and the presence/absence of the 'pre-filled' banner. Test with hosts who have real pricing context (actual property owners) to ensure the default values feel realistic.

elements.title: Validate Human Thread: Agent Accessibility as Psychological Safety Net
elements.problem: feels-008 asserts that the host must always feel one step from a real person. The 'Message Bryant' action must be within 2 taps from any screen. The agent's presence is a safety net -- most hosts will not use it, but knowing it is there reduces anxiety.
elements.solution: Test whether the persistent visibility of the agent contact action reduces confusion-related abandonment and support tickets.

evidence.insight: Andreas establishes a permanent human channel: 'You can just email me at any time.' The platform must never replace this expectation.
The feeling of connection to Bryant is genuine. The platform risks creating a cognitive illusion by showing the photo without real accessibility.

elements.test_description: Track: (1) visibility of the 'Message [agent name]' action (is it accessible within 2 taps from every authenticated screen?), (2) usage rate (what percentage of hosts use the agent messaging action?), (3) correlation between agent-message visibility and confusion-related abandonment (do hosts who encounter the agent contact at a confusion point continue versus hosts who encounter a FAQ or help center?), (4) support ticket analysis: are tickets phrased as 'I could not reach my agent' or 'the system did not work'? The first indicates the human thread is valued but broken; the second indicates it was never relied upon.
elements.success_criteria: Agent contact action is accessible in 2 or fewer taps from 100% of authenticated screens (automated accessibility audit). Usage rate is between 5-15% (low usage indicates the safety net is working -- hosts feel safe without needing to actually use it). Confusion-related abandonment is at least 20% lower on screens where the agent contact is visible versus screens where it is not. Support tickets mentioning the agent by name indicate relationship (positive), not frustration (negative).
elements.failure_meaning: If usage rate exceeds 20%, the platform itself may be too confusing, forcing hosts to rely on human support. This is a platform design problem, not a safety net success. If usage rate is 0%, the agent contact may be too hidden or hosts may not realize it connects to a real person. If abandonment is not affected by agent visibility, the human thread may not be the safety mechanism for this audience -- they may prefer self-service help content.
elements.implementation_hint: Run an automated audit of all authenticated pages to verify the 2-tap agent-access constraint. Track agent_message_opened events with the originating page as context. Create a dashboard showing usage rate by page to identify screens where hosts most need the human safety net.

elements.title: Journey-Level Validation: End-to-End Conversion from Call to Published Listing
elements.problem: Individual element validations test specific design decisions, but the host journey is a connected sequence where each phase's success depends on the prior phase. The end-to-end conversion from completed phone call to published listing is the ultimate test of whether the design stack's principles work together: System 1 trust gates pass, depletion is managed, speed matches the call, trust transfers from human to digital, and the host completes the full wizard.
elements.solution: Track the end-to-end funnel from phone call completion to published listing as the primary success metric for the entire design stack.

evidence.insight: 8 reinforcement clusters show that multiple layers converge on the same principles. The end-to-end funnel tests whether these converging principles actually produce the intended outcome: a host who went from call to published listing without dropping off.

System 1 trust gating, progressive depletion, priming transfer, and the human-to-digital handoff are all cross-phase patterns that can only be validated by measuring the entire journey, not individual phases.

elements.test_description: Build a cohort-based funnel analysis tracking every host from phone call completion through published listing. Funnel stages: (1) phone call completed, (2) onboarding email sent, (3) onboarding email opened, (4) first platform visit, (5) listing wizard started, (6) listing wizard Step 3 reached (past the typical depletion dropout point), (7) listing published. Track conversion rate at each stage, time between stages, and the total time from call to published listing. Segment by agent, property type, and number of units. Run weekly cohort reports to track improvement as design elements are implemented.
elements.success_criteria: End-to-end conversion rate (call completed to listing published) above 40%. Time from call to published listing under 48 hours for 60% of converting hosts. No single funnel stage shows a conversion rate below 60% (no stage is a black hole). The highest dropout stage should be identifiable and addressable.
elements.failure_meaning: If end-to-end conversion is below 40%, identify which stage is the primary bottleneck. If Stage 3 (email opened) to Stage 4 (first platform visit) is the weakest link, the trust bridge (works-004, communicates-006) is failing. If Stage 5 (wizard started) to Stage 6 (Step 3 reached) is weakest, depletion design (works-002, feels-004) is failing. If Stage 6 to Stage 7 (published) is weakest, the later wizard steps need simplification. The funnel diagnosis points directly to which design element cluster needs attention.
elements.implementation_hint: Integrate CRM data (phone call events) with platform analytics (user actions) using a shared host identifier. Build the funnel in the analytics platform with stage timestamps. Create a weekly dashboard showing the funnel with conversion rates, median time between stages, and week-over-week trends. Flag any stage where conversion drops below 50% for immediate investigation.

elements.title: Journey-Level Validation: Emotional Arc Consistency from Discovery to Active Lease
elements.problem: Layer 5 defines a progressive emotional arc: calm (discovery) -> relief (evaluation/pricing) -> confidence (listing creation) -> momentum (wizard) -> safety (active lease). If any phase breaks the emotional progression -- a warm call followed by a cold platform, or a confident listing creation followed by an anxious proposal experience -- the associative coherence is disrupted and the host's cumulative trust erodes.
elements.solution: Conduct longitudinal sentiment tracking across the full host journey, measuring whether the emotional arc progresses as designed or breaks at specific transitions.

evidence.insight: The designed arc is: calm -> relief -> confidence -> momentum -> safety -> curiosity. Each phase builds on the emotional foundation of the prior phase.
The coherence auditor confirms the arc is progressive and conflict-free. No phase targets an emotion that contradicts a prior phase.

elements.test_description: Longitudinal qualitative study with 4-6 hosts tracked from phone call through first proposal acceptance (approximately 2-4 weeks). At each phase transition, conduct a brief check-in (5 minutes, via the host's preferred channel -- likely text or email): 'One word: how are you feeling about the process right now?' and 'Is there anything about the experience that surprised you -- positively or negatively?' Compile the single-word emotional descriptors across phases for each host and map them against the designed arc. At the final check-in (after proposal acceptance), conduct a 15-minute retrospective interview: 'Walk me through the journey from your phone call to now. Where did things feel smooth? Where did things feel off?'
elements.success_criteria: At least 3 of 5 hosts show an emotional trajectory that matches the designed arc (calm -> positive growth, not calm -> frustration). No host reports an emotional regression (e.g., confident at listing creation but anxious at proposal review) at any transition. Retrospective interviews identify no more than 1 significant emotional break point per host. The most common single-word descriptors across all hosts are neutral-to-positive ('easy,' 'fine,' 'good,' 'smooth') rather than negative ('confusing,' 'frustrating,' 'slow').
elements.failure_meaning: If hosts report emotional regression at a specific transition, that transition is the weakest link in the emotional arc and the design elements governing it need revision. If multiple hosts identify the same break point, the problem is systematic (a design flaw) rather than individual (a host-specific circumstance). If the most common descriptors are negative, the overall experience is failing regardless of individual element quality -- the gestalt is broken even if parts work.
elements.implementation_hint: Recruit hosts at the phone call stage (coordinate with the sales team). Schedule check-ins at natural phase boundaries: immediately after the call, after first platform visit, after listing publication, after first proposal notification, after proposal action. Use text-based check-ins to minimize effort. Record the retrospective interview for qualitative analysis. This is a high-touch study that should run quarterly with small cohorts.

elements.title: Transparent Economics Before Commitment
elements.problem: Professional hosts evaluate Split Lease primarily through an economic lens: 'Will this partnership yield competitive returns vs. my traditional revenue streams?' Jessica spent 6+ minutes (06:29-12:52) negotiating the pricing model because the economics were unclear. Robert's initial answer ('$1,450-$1,500 per month') was immediately challenged by Jessica as unrealistic for Manhattan. The back-and-forth consumed cognitive resources and created uncertainty. When Robert finally explained the markup model ('You give me the price, which is already marked up with your fee. I don't want to know how much you marked up.'), he used autonomy language to build trust, but he also left Jessica without benchmarks. She doesn't know: (1) What markup percentage is typical? (2) How price-sensitive are Split Lease guests? (3) How long does conversion take? Without this data, Jessica is pricing blind, which increases her risk of either under-pricing (losing profit) or over-pricing (losing conversions).
elements.solution: Provide transparent economic benchmarks during evaluation, before the host commits time to listing creation. This means: (1) The broker partnership page should include a pricing calculator: 'Enter your base rent, see estimated markup range that converts, see projected commission over 3/6/12 months.' (2) Share conversion data: 'Listings priced at $X convert in Y days on average. Listings priced above $Z convert in 2x days.' (3) Compare Split Lease economics to traditional broker fees with concrete examples: 'Traditional broker fee: 1 month rent upfront ($2,000). Split Lease model: $50/day markup over 6 months = $9,000 total commission. You earn 4.5x more, paid over time.' (4) Provide a 'recommended markup' based on property type, location, and lease duration. Allow hosts to override, but give them a starting point grounded in conversion data. The pattern is: show the math first, then let hosts decide.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'What's the price range that you'd be looking for?' Robert: '$1,450 or $1,500 a month for the apartment.' Jessica: 'Or 1500 per person or per apartment? Because like, let's say for example, lower east side. There's nothing available at all for 14 to 15 hundreds. For Manhattan, it's very expensive. I could find something maybe for 2000 a studio for maybe 1900, 2000.'
evidence.insight: Jessica challenges Robert's pricing expectations because she has superior market knowledge. She's the authority on Manhattan real estate, and Robert's lack of pricing transparency undermines his credibility. This dynamic wastes time and creates doubt about whether Split Lease understands the market.

evidence.quote: Robert: 'You give me the price, which is already marked up with your fee. I don't want to know how much you marked up. You just give me a surprise, including your fees, whatever you feel reasonable that is yours. I'm not interfering with you.'
evidence.insight: Robert uses autonomy language ('I don't want to know your markup') to build trust, but this shifts all pricing risk to Jessica. If she prices wrong and listings don't convert, she'll blame the model, not her pricing decision. Providing benchmarks would reduce this risk.

evidence.quote: Because their positions speak of superior access to information and power, it makes great sense to comply with the wishes of properly constituted authorities.
evidence.insight: Split Lease should position itself as the pricing authority by sharing proprietary conversion data. 'We've processed 1,000+ bookings and know what pricing works' is an authority signal that makes hosts more likely to accept pricing guidance.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I have to run it by my broker, but I am interested.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's conditional commitment ('I have to run it by my broker') signals that she doesn't yet have enough economic data to internally justify the partnership. If the economics were crystal clear ('You'll earn 4.5x a traditional broker fee'), she could present a stronger case to her broker.

elements.user_goal: Understand exactly how much money I'll make from this partnership compared to my traditional revenue streams, with concrete examples and conversion timelines, before I invest time creating listings.
elements.company_goal: Increase broker commitment rates by providing transparent economic benchmarks that demonstrate Split Lease's value proposition, reducing pricing uncertainty and enabling hosts to make data-driven decisions.
elements.time_budget: Host should be able to model their economics in under 2 minutes using a pricing calculator. Evaluation call should spend <3 minutes on pricing discussion, with most questions answered by pre-call materials.
anti_goals: DO NOT use 'whatever you feel reasonable' as pricing guidance. Autonomy is valuable, but hosts need benchmarks to make informed decisions.
DO NOT withhold conversion data under the assumption that hosts will experiment. Professional hosts optimize for ROI and need data upfront.
DO NOT assume hosts understand the daily rate model. Many are accustomed to monthly rent + upfront broker fees. Translate Split Lease's model into familiar terms.
DO NOT let pricing discussions dominate evaluation calls. Economics should be transparent before the call, allowing calls to focus on partnership logistics.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of broker hosts who create their first listing within 48 hours of the evaluation call. Target: 60%. Secondary: average markup percentage within 10% of Split Lease's recommended range for that property type.

elements.title: Relationship Capital Through Honest Constraints
elements.problem: Robert used Cialdini's 'seeming to argue against his own interests' tactic (like Vincent the waiter) to build trust with Jessica. When she suggested $1,900-$2,000 studios, Robert responded honestly: 'Pricing things out of the market would be no interest to anybody.' He then advised her to 'start with rooms or studios or one bedrooms. Try to go on the lower cost.' This honesty signalRobert telling Jessica that her higher-priced inventory won't convertbuilt credibility and warmed the relationship. Jessica ended the call saying 'That sounds good to me. Thank you so much, Robert.' However, this pattern is agent-dependent (requires Robert's skill and judgment) and doesn't scale. Most hosts won't receive this honest, constraining advice, leaving them to discover through failed conversions that their inventory is mispriced.
elements.solution: Systematize honest constraint feedback as a process pattern across the host journey, not a person-dependent tactic. This means: (1) During listing creation, provide real-time feedback: 'Properties in this area at this price typically convert in 30+ days. Reducing price by 15% cuts conversion time to 10 days.' (2) Flag overpriced listings before they go live: 'This listing is priced 20% above comparable properties. Consider adjusting to improve conversion.' (3) After 7 days with no proposals, proactively reach out: 'Your listing hasn't received proposals yet. Based on our data, reducing the daily rate from $X to $Y would increase visibility 3x.' (4) Display 'recommended adjustments' in the host dashboard that show exactly what changes (price, photos, description) would improve conversion likelihood. (5) Use the same 'arguing against our own interests' frame: 'We want you to succeed, and that means sometimes telling you when a listing won't work as currently priced.' The pattern is: build relationship capital by being the honest authority, even when it constrains short-term revenue.

evidence.quote: Robert: 'Please start with rooms or studios or one bedrooms. Try to go on the whatever law was cost. You can go and we will go for themselves and maybe go into the higher ones because pricing things out of the market would be no interest to anybody.'
evidence.insight: Robert constrains Jessica's inventory choices by telling her that high-priced Manhattan inventory won't convert. This is honest advice that argues against Split Lease's short-term interests (fewer listings to market) but builds long-term trust. Jessica accepts this constraint because it demonstrates Robert's expertise and goodwill.

evidence.source: cialdini-authority-liking-scarcity.txt, Vincent the waiter example (from journey-context.json reference)
evidence.quote: Vincent's maneuver engaged several important principles of influence. First, even those who did not take his suggestions felt that Vincent had done them a favor by offering valuable information to help them order. Everyone felt grateful... Moreoverand this is where seeming to argue against his own interests came init proved him to be a trustworthy informant, because he recommended dishes that were slightly less expensive than originally ordered.
evidence.insight: Vincent built trust by recommending cheaper dishes, which argued against the restaurant's (and his own) short-term interests but maximized customer satisfaction. Robert mirrors this by telling Jessica to send lower-cost inventory, which argues against Split Lease's short-term interest (fewer high-value listings) but maximizes Jessica's conversion success.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I'll email you. You can expect to hear from me by Friday.' [Later:] 'That sounds good to me. Thank you so much, Robert.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's tone shifted from skeptical (01:01-03:00) to warm and committed (18:54-19:03) after Robert's honest constraint advice. She went from interrogating the model to thanking Robert warmly. This emotional shift signals relationship capital was built through honest guidance.

evidence.quote: Robert: 'I tell you what, why don't we place that. And if our clients decide to take it, they will take it because a lot of people are quite desperate because they cannot find what they need. And the alternative is hotels and hotels are much more expensive.'
evidence.insight: When Jessica pushed back on pricing, Robert didn't insist she was wrong. Instead, he offered to test her theory ('why don't we place that') while explaining the competitive context (hotels are more expensive). This collaborative approach'let's test it together'builds partnership rather than hierarchy.

elements.user_goal: Receive honest, expert guidance about what will and won't work, even when it means being told my initial approach needs adjustment. Feel like Split Lease is on my side, optimizing for my success rather than just getting listings live.
elements.company_goal: Build long-term host retention and referral rates by being the trusted authority who provides honest feedback, even when it constrains short-term listings volume. Hosts who trust Split Lease's guidance will send better inventory and price it correctly, improving overall conversion rates.
elements.time_budget: Constraint feedback should be instant (real-time during listing creation) or proactive (within 7 days of low performance). Hosts should not have to discover through failure what Split Lease's data could have predicted.
anti_goals: DO NOT accept all listings without feedback. Silence implies approval, and hosts will interpret lack of guidance as validation of their pricing/inventory choices.
DO NOT wait for hosts to ask for advice. Proactive constraint feedback (delivered respectfully) builds authority and trust.
DO NOT use generic messaging like 'Consider adjusting your price.' Provide specific, data-driven recommendations: 'Reducing price from $X to $Y will cut conversion time from 30 days to 10 days.'
DO NOT frame constraint feedback as criticism. Use collaborative language: 'Based on what's converting right now, here's an adjustment that would help this listing perform better.'
elements.success_metric: Host Net Promoter Score (NPS) measured after first 3 months. Target: 50+ NPS. Secondary: percentage of hosts who adjust pricing within 7 days of receiving constraint feedback. Target: 70%.

elements.title: Scarcity Validation Through Early Proof
elements.problem: Robert opened the call with a scarcity frame: 'We have right now too much demand and not enough inventory' (01:54-02:35). This is a classic scarcity tactic designed to signal that Jessica's inventory is valuable and urgently needed. However, Jessica is a sophisticated operator who recognizes sales tactics. She doesn't blindly accept the scarcity claim; she's testing it conditionally ('I'll send a couple of listings by Friday'). If those test listings don't receive proposals quickly, Jessica will conclude the demand story was oversold, and the partnership will stall. Cialdini's research shows that 'newly experienced scarcity is the more powerful kind'meaning scarcity becomes more persuasive when it's verified through direct experience, not just asserted. The current process relies on verbal scarcity claims without providing early proof that validates those claims.

elements.problem: Jessica spent 6+ minutes negotiating pricing ('What's the price range?', 'For Manhattan, it's very expensive') because economics were unclear. The interaction must respond to host's pricing inputs (base rent, lease duration) by instantly updating ROI comparison, reducing cognitive load from internal mental math to external visual feedback.
elements.solution: Build real-time calculator feedback loop that responds to every host input with instant visual updates. Split Lease commission: $9,000 over 6 months (4.5x more).' Loading state: as host types new base rent value, calculator updates in real-timeno submit button, no delay. Use debouncing (300ms after last keystroke) to prevent excessive calculations, but display loading shimmer on comparison cards during debounce period. Success state: after calculation completes, animate updated values using spring easing count-up from old value to new value (e.g., $2,000  $2,400 counts up over 400ms), creating visual drama that emphasizes the change.

Multiplier badge pulses once (scale from 1.0  1.1  1.0 over 300ms) if multiplier increases, drawing attention to improved ROI. Success state creates satisfying feedback loop: input  visual response  improved outcome.

elements.transition_principle: Calculator interactions should feel instantaneous and fluid, never disruptive. Input changes trigger calculations after 300ms debounce (prevents calculation spam while typing), but visual acknowledgment happens immediately (<100ms): input field focus state, cursor position maintained. Value updates use count-up animation (not sudden replacement) to make changes perceivable and emphasize direction of change (increasing commission = positive). Debounce timing balances responsiveness (host doesn't wait long) with computational efficiency (not recalculating on every keystroke).

timing.response_target: 50ms for input focus acknowledgment; 300ms debounce before calculation; 400ms for value count-up animation
timing.easing: spring (cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1)) for value count-up creates satisfying bounce at end; out (cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)) for shimmer fade-in

Spring easing adds delight to value updates, creating micro-celebration of improved economics.

Display helper text: 'Adjust inputs to match your inventory.' Pricing phase (host creating first listing): Pre-populate calculator with their actual listing data from listing creation form. Display comparison: 'Your listing at $X/day generates $Y commission vs. $Z traditional fee.' Host sees real economics for their specific property, not hypothetical example.
edge_cases: Host enters extremely high base rent ($20,000/month penthouse): Calculator displays warning banner (signal-warn-bg): 'High-priced properties may have longer conversion times. See pricing guidance below.' Calculation still completes, but host is warned about market realities.

Host adjusts lease duration to <1 month: Display informational banner (signal-info-bg): 'Split Lease specializes in 3+ month leases. Short-term rentals may not be available in all markets.' Calculation completes but expectations are managed.

Host on mobile device with limited screen width: Switch calculator layout from side-by-side comparison cards to stacked vertical layout. Maintain same interaction pattern (real-time updates, count-up animations) but optimize for vertical scrolling.

Host rapidly changes inputs (slider dragging, rapid typing): Throttle calculation updates to maximum 3 per second to prevent animation jank. Visual feedback (shimmer) continues on every input, but actual calculations are throttled for performance.

By the end of the call (18:54-19:03), her tone shifted to conditional optimism: 'That sounds good to me. Thank you so much, Robert.' This emotional arcfrom skeptical to warmwas driven by Robert's use of Cialdini's 'seeming to argue against his own interests' tactic: he told Jessica that $1,450-$1,500 pricing won't work and recommended lower-cost inventory, arguing against Split Lease's short-term interest (fewer high-value listings) but maximizing Jessica's conversion success. The challenge: how do we systematize this emotional transition from skepticism to trust across the host journey when not every host gets a skilled agent like Robert?

Onboarding: acknowledge host expertise ('You know your markethere's data to complement your judgment') rather than claiming superior knowledge. elements.title: Communication Channel Preference Capture
elements.problem: At 18:07-18:14, Jessica explicitly states: 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.' This is critical operational intelligence. If Split Lease sends proposals, listing updates, or guest communications via email (the default channel), Jessica may miss them entirely. She's a busy broker managing multiple deals across multiple channels. Email overload is a real constraint for her. Missing a guest proposal notification because it arrived via email when she prefers text could cost her a conversion and erode trust. The current process doesn't systematically capture or honor communication channel preferences, leaving hosts to discover through missed messages that the default channel doesn't work for them.
elements.solution: Capture communication channel preferences during onboarding and systematically honor them across all journey phases. This means: (1) During the first post-call follow-up, ask explicitly: 'How would you prefer to receive time-sensitive notifications (proposals, guest questions, booking confirmations)? Email, text, or both?' (2) Store this preference in the host profile and display it prominently in the dashboard: 'Notifications: Text preferred (updated 2 days ago).' (3) Route time-sensitive communications (proposals arriving, guest questions, booking confirmations) through the preferred channel. Route non-urgent communications (weekly summaries, platform updates) through email by default. (4) Allow hosts to update preferences anytime via dashboard settings. (5) When sending the first notification via the preferred channel, acknowledge the preference: 'You'll receive this via text, as you requested. You can change this anytime in settings.' The pattern is: ask once, honor consistently, make changes easy.

If Split Lease sends time-sensitive notifications via a channel she doesn't monitor closely (email), she may miss them, leading to delayed responses or abandoned proposals. elements.company_goal: Increase proposal response rates and reduce host-side delays by ensuring time-sensitive communications reach hosts via their preferred channels. Reduce 'host didn't respond' proposal failures by 30%.

elements.title: Confidentiality Assurance Module: Visual Trust Gate
elements.problem: Jessica demanded 'I would need for you to sign something with me, a confidentiality agreement' because Robert hadn't established trust through transparency about relationship protection. Professional hosts (brokers, property managers) operate in environments where protecting client relationships is paramount. If Split Lease bypasses the host and contacts landlords directly, the host loses reputation and revenue. Jessica's defensive posture signals information asymmetry: she doesn't understand how Split Lease's process protects her interests. Visual challenge: How do we proactively address confidentiality concerns through visual design before hosts raise them defensively? Text-heavy legal explanations fail to leverage visual processing advantages for trust-building. Visual trust signals (checkmarks, shields, protective imagery) combined with clear typography hierarchy can communicate 'your relationships are safe' more effectively than paragraphs of text.
elements.solution: Design a visual confidentiality assurance module that uses typography, color, iconography, and spatial hierarchy to communicate relationship protection. Primary visual layer: 'How We Protect Your Relationships' section on broker partnership page. Hero element: shield icon ( 64px) in accent color (#2d5a3d) symbolizing protection. Below shield, three protection principles as vertically stacked cards (surface-warm with border, shadow-sm). Each card shows: checkmark icon ( 24px, accent-bright), principle headline (Instrument Serif 20px bold, ink), explanation (Outfit 16px regular, ink-soft). Visual hierarchy: shield icon  principle headlines  explanations. Spacing: xl (40px) vertical rhythm between cards creates clear separation. Secondary visual layer: Downloadable template confidentiality agreement as prominent CTA button (accent background, surface text, rounded-lg radius). Button shows: document icon ( 20px) + label 'Download Template Agreement' (Outfit 16px bold). Position below protection principles, suggesting logical flow: understand protection  review template  proceed with confidence. Tertiary visual layer: Dashboard 'Relationship Protection' panel using signal-info-bg (#e8f0fa) with signal-info border. Shows recent listing access events as timeline: timestamp (IBM Plex Mono 14px regular, ink-muted) + actor ('Split Lease team member') + action ('viewed your listing') + listing name (Outfit 14px medium, ink). Visual hierarchy: timeline events top-to-bottom (most recent first), 'View all' link at bottom.

elements.title: Scarcity Proof Progressive Evidence Accumulation
elements.problem: Robert claimed 'We have too much demand and not enough inventory,' but Jessica recognized this as a sales tactic and responded cautiously ('I'll send a couple of listings by Friday'). Cialdini explains that 'newly experienced scarcity is the more powerful kind'scarcity must be verified through direct experience, not asserted. If Jessica's test listings receive no proposals within 7 days, she'll conclude demand was oversold. The interaction must convert verbal scarcity claims into progressive evidence accumulation: initial demand proof (within 24 hours of commitment)  real-time engagement metrics (within 48 hours of listing live)  conversion velocity celebration (when proposal arrives). Each evidence layer builds on previous, creating cumulative persuasion through direct experience.
elements.solution: Build progressive evidence accumulation system that responds to host's journey milestones with demand proof. Default state (within 24 hours of evaluation call commitment): Send email with 'Your Waitlist Snapshot' showing 5 active guest searches matching host's inventory profile. Each search displays as card: guest persona icon, budget range (IBM Plex Mono, accent-bright), move-in timeline. Loading state (within 48 hours of listing going live): Dashboard displays real-time engagement metrics with count-up animations: 'Your listing has been viewed by [23] guests' (number counts from 0 to 23 over 800ms using spring easing). Metrics update every 60 seconds with smooth number transitions (not sudden jumps). Success state (when first proposal arrives): Display celebration banner across dashboard top: ' First proposal in 4 days  faster than 7-day average!' with confetti animation (subtle, 2-second duration). Banner includes CTA: 'Review Proposal ' (accent button).

evidence.quote: Robert: 'Right now, the way we operate is if we find we have, unfortunately we have right now too much demand and not enough inventory.'
evidence.insight: Robert's verbal scarcity claim needs experiential validation. Jessica won't fully believe 'too much demand' until she sees her listings receiving proposals. Interaction pattern must convert claim into progressive proof: waitlist snapshot (initial evidence)  engagement metrics (ongoing validation)  proposal arrival (conclusive proof).

evidence.quote: The idea that newly experienced scarcity is the more powerful kind applies to situations well beyond the bounds of the cookie study.
evidence.insight: Newly experienced scarcity (watching your listing's view count increase in real-time) is more persuasive than described scarcity (being told there's high demand). Interaction must make scarcity visible and dynamic through progressive metric updates, not static claims.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I'll see if I can get a couple [of listings].'
evidence.insight: Jessica commits cautiously ('a couple'), testing whether demand is real. Interaction timing is critical: evidence must arrive within days (not weeks) to validate scarcity claim before host concludes it was oversold. Day 1: waitlist snapshot. Day 2-3: engagement metrics. Day 4-7: proposal arrival (if pricing is good).

evidence.quote: spring: cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1)
evidence.insight: Spring easing for metric count-up animations creates visual drama that emphasizes growing demand. As view count increases from 18  23, spring easing creates slight overshoot at end, drawing eye to the growth and reinforcing 'demand is increasing' message.

evidence.quote: Scarcity Proof Visualization: 'Use spring animation to count up from 0 to actual number, creating visual drama that emphasizes growing demand. Engagement metrics update with smooth number transitions.'
evidence.insight: Layer 3 defined animation style for scarcity proof. Layer 4 adds interaction trigger timing: count-up animation fires on initial page load (0  current value) and on metric updates (every 60 seconds, previous value  new value). Host sees demand growing in real-time through animated feedback.

states.default: Dashboard 'Listing Performance' section displays engagement metrics in stat card format: 'Views: 0', 'Saves: 0', 'Matched Searches: 0' (IBM Plex Mono 32px bold, ink). Below metrics, placeholder text (Outfit 16px, ink-soft): 'Metrics will update within 24 hours of your listing going live.' Default state sets expectations for when evidence will appear.
states.loading: When listing goes live and first metrics arrive (within 48 hours), trigger count-up animations: 'Views' counts from 0  18 over 800ms (spring easing), then 'Saves' counts from 0  3 (staggered by 200ms for cascading effect), then 'Matched Searches' counts from 0  5. During count-up, numbers pulse subtly (scale 1.0  1.05  1.0). Loading state creates visual event that signals 'your listing is getting attention.'
states.empty: If listing has been live for 24 hours but has 0 views (unusual, suggests technical issue), display informational banner (signal-info-bg): 'We're still presenting your listing to guests. Metrics typically appear within 48 hours. [Check listing status ]' Empty state reassures host and provides action path if concerned.
states.error: If metrics API fails or times out, display cached metrics from last successful fetch with timestamp: 'Views: 18 (as of 2 hours ago)' (IBM Plex Mono 32px, ink-muted for timestamp). Below metrics, error banner (signal-danger-bg): 'Unable to load latest data. [Retry]'. Error state preserves last known information while acknowledging staleness.
states.success: When first proposal arrives, trigger celebration sequence: (1) Confetti animation launches from proposal notification area (2-second duration, subtle multi-colored dots using accent, signal-info, signal-warn colors). (2) Banner slides down from top of dashboard (400ms spring easing): ' First proposal in 4 days  faster than 7-day average!' (Instrument Serif 20px bold, accent text on accent-light-bg). (3) Proposal notification badge pulses (scale 1.0  1.3  1.0, 600ms, draws eye). Success state creates micro-celebration that validates scarcity claim through tangible outcome.

elements.transition_principle: Scarcity proof accumulation should feel like evidence building over time, not sudden revelations. Metric count-up animations use staggered timing (200ms delays between metrics) to create cascading effecthost sees metrics populating sequentially, suggesting 'data is arriving.' Spring easing on count-ups creates organic motion that feels less robotic, more human. Celebration sequence (confetti + banner + badge pulse) is orchestrated with intentional timing: confetti draws initial attention, banner provides context, badge pulse directs to action. Each transition reinforces the narrative: 'Demand exists  Your listing is getting attention  A guest wants to book.'

timing.response_target: 800ms for each metric count-up; 200ms stagger between metrics; 2-second confetti animation; 400ms banner slide-down
timing.easing: spring (cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1)) for metric count-up and banner slide; out (cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)) for confetti fade-out
timing.rationale: 800ms count-up is slow enough to be perceived and enjoyed (host watches numbers climb) but fast enough not to feel sluggish. 200ms stagger creates pleasing cascade effect without extending total animation duration excessively. 2-second confetti animation is celebratory without being annoying (auto-dismisses, no manual close needed). Spring easing throughout creates cohesive motion language that signals 'positive, organic growth' vs. mechanical updates.

elements.journey_state_awareness: Evaluation phase (host just committed to sending listings): Waitlist snapshot email is primary scarcity proofshow 5 active guest searches to validate 'too much demand' claim before host even creates listings. Proposal management phase (host has listings live, waiting for proposals): Real-time engagement metrics (views, saves) provide ongoing validation while host waits. Each metric update reinforces 'your listing is being seen.' Active lease phase (proposal arrived, host reviewing): Conversion velocity celebration ('4 days vs. 7-day average') provides comparison that validates scarcity through competitive framing ('your listing was in demand faster than typical').
edge_cases: Host's listing is in low-demand market (small city, unusual property type): Display engagement metrics with market context: 'Views: 8  above average for [market name].' Reframe 'low' absolute numbers as 'good' relative performance to maintain host confidence.

Listing receives high views (50+) but no saves or proposals (suggests pricing issue): After 5 days of this pattern, display guidance banner (signal-warn-bg): 'Your listing has strong visibility (50 views) but guests aren't saving it. Consider reducing price by 10-15% to increase conversion.' Link engagement pattern to actionable recommendation.

Proposal arrives very slowly (15+ days, slower than average): Celebration banner adjusts framing: 'First proposal received! Here's the guest profile for your review.' (No velocity comparison if it's unflattering). Celebration focuses on outcome (proposal arrived) not timing.

Multiple proposals arrive simultaneously (3 proposals in same day): Celebration banner emphasizes competition: ' 3 proposals in 24 hours! Your listing is in high demand. Review proposals to choose best fit.' Scarcity framing shifts from 'demand exists' to 'competitive demand' (Cialdini: demand-driven scarcity is most powerful).

Host has multiple listings, varying performance: Dashboard shows comparative metrics: 'Listing A: 23 views. Listing B: 8 views (below average).' Comparison creates internal benchmarkhost sees which listings are performing and can investigate why (pricing, photos, description) without platform needing to diagnose.

elements.title: Economic Uncertainty to Confident Commitment
elements.problem: Jessica spent 6+ minutes (06:29-12:52) in economic uncertainty, negotiating pricing because she couldn't model her returns. She challenged Robert's expectations ('For Manhattan, it's very expensive'), asked for benchmarks ('What's the price range?'), and needed multiple clarifications on the markup model. Her emotional state was calculating but anxious: 'Will this yield competitive returns vs. my traditional broker fee?' When Robert finally said 'You give me the price, already marked up with your fee. I don't want to know how much you marked up,' he used autonomy language to build trust but left Jessica pricing blind. She doesn't know what markup is typical, how price-sensitive guests are, or how long conversion takes. Without transparent economics, hosts experience economic anxiety: 'Am I leaving money on the table?' or 'Am I pricing myself out of conversions?' The emotional challenge: how do we transition hosts from economic uncertainty to confident commitment through transparent, interactive ROI modeling?
elements.solution: Design the journey to replace economic anxiety with confident commitment through progressive economic transparency. Evaluation phase: show ROI comparison immediately (traditional broker fee vs. Split Lease commission with multiplier: '4.5x more commission'). Pricing phase: provide interactive calculator that updates in real-time as host adjusts inputs, showing projected commission over 3/6/12 months, conversion timelines for different price points, and recommended markup range based on comparable listings. Listing creation: display pricing confidence indicators (green zone = recommended, yellow = slower conversion, red = rarely converts) with specific data ('Properties at this price convert in 30 days vs. 10-day average for $100-125 range'). Throughout: use precise, data-anchored language (not vague 'competitive returns') and animate value updates with spring easing to create visual drama that emphasizes growing commission.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'What's the price range?' Robert: '$1,450 or $1,500.' Jessica: 'For Manhattan, it's very expensive. I could find something maybe for 2000 a studio for maybe 1900, 2000.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's emotional state during pricing discussion is uncertain and defensive. She's challenging Robert's expectations because she has superior market knowledge but no benchmarks for Split Lease's model. Economic uncertainty manifests as defensive correction: 'You're wrong about Manhattan pricing.'

evidence.quote: Robert: 'You give me the price, which is already marked up with your fee. I don't want to know how much you marked up. You just give me a surprise, including your fees, whatever you feel reasonable.'
evidence.insight: Robert's autonomy language ('whatever you feel reasonable') sounds empowering but emotionally it leaves Jessica unsupported. She's now responsible for pricing success or failure without benchmarks. Emotional state: autonomous but anxious ('What if I get this wrong?').

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I have to run it by my broker, but I am interested.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's conditional commitment ('I have to run it by my broker') signals residual economic uncertainty. She's interested but doesn't yet have enough data to internally justify the partnership. If economics were crystal clear, she could present a stronger case to her broker.

evidence.quote: Because their positions speak of superior access to information and power, it makes great sense to comply with the wishes of properly constituted authorities.
evidence.insight: Split Lease should position itself as the pricing authority by sharing proprietary conversion data. Transparent data reduces host anxiety by establishing Split Lease as the credible source of 'what pricing works,' allowing hosts to defer to expertise rather than guess.

elements.emotion_rationale: Hosts commit when they feel confident in their economic model, not when they're anxious about whether they're pricing correctly or leaving money on the table.

copy_guidelines.voice: Transparent data partner, not mysterious platform
do: Show concrete ROI comparisons: 'Traditional broker fee: $2,000 upfront. Split Lease model: $50/day markup over 6 months = $9,000 total. You earn 4.5x more.'
Provide specific conversion benchmarks: 'Listings priced at $100-125/day convert in 10 days on average. Above $150/day: 30+ days.'
Explain why recommendations serve host: 'We recommend this price range because it maximizes your total commission through faster conversion and higher occupancy.'
Animate value updates to create visual drama: When host adjusts calculator inputs, commission value counts up from previous to new amount, emphasizing growth
dont: Use vague language: 'Competitive returns' or 'Good earning potential' (too generic, doesn't reduce anxiety)
Withhold conversion data: 'Try different prices and see what works' (shifts risk entirely to host)
Hide revenue conflicts: If Split Lease benefits from higher prices that don't convert, say nothing (destroys trust)
Provide autonomy without benchmarks: 'Whatever you feel is reasonable' (sounds empowering but leaves host anxious)
copy_guidelines.example_good: Based on 150 comparable listings in Manhattan, properties priced at $110-120/day convert in 8 days and generate $19,800 commission over 6 months. Pricing at $150/day typically takes 30 days to convert and generates $27,000 totalhigher commission but longer wait and higher vacancy risk.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: You can set whatever price you want! We support your decision and think you'll do great. Just enter your preferred daily rate and we'll take it from there.

animation_feel.feel_description: Satisfying bounce at the end of value transitions that emphasizes the final number. Creates micro-celebration of commission growth that builds emotional confidence: 'Look how much you're earning!'
animation_feel.duration_range: 400-800ms for value count-up animations (slow enough to be perceived and enjoyed, fast enough not to delay workflow)

tension_relief.tension_point: Pricing phase: 'Am I pricing correctly? Will I earn enough? Will my listings convert or sit idle?'
tension_relief.relief_point: Interactive calculator shows projected commission + conversion timeline + comparison to traditional fee, all updating in real-time as host adjusts inputs
tension_relief.timing: Relief arrives immediately when host accesses calculator (within first 30 seconds of pricing exploration). Instant feedback loop: adjust input  see outcome  feel confident.

personalization_signals: Pre-populate calculator with host's actual market data: If host is in Manhattan, show Manhattan-specific conversion benchmarks, not national averages
Reference host's current revenue model: 'Compared to your traditional broker fee of [X], Split Lease would generate [Y] over [Z] months'
Adapt recommendations to host's inventory: 'For your studio listings, we recommend $110-125/day based on 45 comparable properties in your area'

anti_patterns.pattern: Autonomy without support: 'You decide the price, we trust your judgment!'
anti_patterns.reason: Sounds empowering but emotionally abandons the host. They wanted guidance, not full responsibility. Economic anxiety persists: 'What if I get this wrong and nothing converts?'
anti_patterns.example_bad: You're the expert on your market! Set whatever price feels right to you. We'll support whatever you decide.

anti_patterns.pattern: Vague earnings promises: 'Earn more with Split Lease!'
anti_patterns.reason: Generic claims without specific data don't reduce economic anxietythey increase skepticism. Hosts need numbers: how much more, over what timeframe, compared to what.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Split Lease hosts earn significantly more than traditional models. Our innovative approach maximizes your earning potential!

anti_patterns.pattern: Hiding pricing complexity to seem simple
anti_patterns.reason: Professional hosts like Jessica aren't looking for 'simple'they're looking for transparent and data-driven. Hiding conversion data or markup implications to avoid complexity creates anxiety, not confidence.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Don't worry about the details! Just give us your base rent and we'll handle the rest. It's super easy!

elements.title: Communication Overload to Respected Efficiency
elements.problem: At 18:07-18:14, Jessica stated: 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.' This brief comment reveals a deeper emotional state: communication overload and the anxiety that comes with it. Jessica is a busy broker managing multiple deals, clients, and properties. Email is where important messages get buried and missed. Her preference for text isn't just convenienceit's a coping mechanism for information overload. If Split Lease defaults to email for time-sensitive notifications (proposals arriving, guest questions), Jessica may miss them entirely, leading to emotional frustration ('Why didn't you tell me?') and practical consequences (lost conversions). The emotional challenge: how do we transition hosts from communication anxiety (fear of missing important messages) to respected efficiency (confidence that Split Lease adapts to their workflow)?
elements.solution: Design the journey to demonstrate respect for host's communication preferences and constraints. Onboarding: explicitly ask how host prefers to receive time-sensitive notifications (email, text, both) and explain the distinction (time-sensitive via preferred channel, non-urgent via email). Make preference persistently visible in dashboard header as badge: ' Text preferred  Change' so host sees constant confirmation their preference is active. Proposal management/active lease: route time-sensitive communications (proposals, guest questions, booking confirmations) through preferred channel and acknowledge this: 'You'll receive this via text, as you requested.' Allow easy preference updates anytime. Throughout: use tone that respects busy professionalsconcise, actionable messages, no fluff.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'Text is preferred because you can imagine how many emails I get.'
evidence.insight: Jessica's emotional state is communication overload. Email is an anxiety source for hermessages get lost, urgent things get missed. Her preference for text is about control and efficiency: text guarantees she'll see it. Emotional need: 'Communicate in ways that work for my workflow.'

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I have to run it by my broker, but I am interested.'
evidence.insight: Jessica operates in a high-demand professional environment (broker approval required, multiple priorities, building visits mentioned). She doesn't have time to hunt for emails. If Split Lease sends proposals via email and she misses them, she'll blame Split Lease for poor communication, not herself.

evidence.quote: Jessica: 'I got to go to this building.'
evidence.insight: Jessica is multitasking throughout the callmanaging other deals, visiting buildings, coordinating with clients. Her emotional state is time-constrained and attention-fragmented. Communication needs to be efficient and impossible to miss.

evidence.quote: We like people who are similar to us. Consequently, those who wish to be liked can accomplish that purpose by appearing similar to us in any of a wide variety of ways.
evidence.insight: Honoring Jessica's communication preference is a form of similarity/liking building. By adapting to her workflow (text vs. email), Split Lease demonstrates 'we understand how busy professionals work.' Emotional response: 'They get me. They respect my time.'

elements.emotion_rationale: Hosts experiencing communication overload feel calm when they trust that important messages will reach them through channels they actually monitor, reducing anxiety about missing opportunities.

do: Ask preferences explicitly: 'How would you prefer to receive time-sensitive notifications? Email, text, or both?'
Explain routing logic: 'Time-sensitive notifications (proposals, guest questions) will be sent via text. Non-urgent updates (weekly summaries, platform news) via email.'
Acknowledge preference in action: 'You'll receive this proposal notification via text, as you requested. Change your preference anytime in dashboard settings.'
Keep messages concise and actionable: 'New proposal for your listing at [address]. Guest profile: [persona], [budget], [move-in date]. Review now: [link]'
dont: Assume email is acceptable default: 'We'll send all updates to your email' (ignores professional email overload reality)
Send unnecessary messages: Weekly newsletters, promotional content, platform updates when host just wants transactional notifications (adds to overload)
Use chatty, lengthy language: 'Hey! We're super excited to let you know that...' (wastes busy professional's time)
Bury important information: Subject line 'Split Lease Update' when it's actually a time-sensitive proposal (forces host to open and scan to find urgency)
copy_guidelines.example_good: New proposal: Your listing at 123 Main St received a proposal from Sarah K., young professional, $115/day, moving in Feb 15. Review proposal: [link]. Sent via text as you requested.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Hi Jessica! Hope you're having a great day! We wanted to reach out and let you know that we have some exciting news about one of your listings. A guest has submitted a proposal! We think this is a really great match and you're going to love working with them. Click here to check out all the details in your dashboard. We're here if you have any questions! Talk soon!

animation_feel.feel_description: Smooth, efficient transitions that mirror the emotional state of calm efficiency. No bouncy playfulnessprofessional and assured. Preference badge appears with subtle fade-in, confirmation banner slides down smoothly.
animation_feel.duration_range: 300-400ms for preference-related transitions (badge appearing, confirmation banner sliding in)

tension_relief.tension_point: Onboarding/ongoing: 'Will I miss important notifications because they get buried in email? How do I make sure Split Lease reaches me?'
tension_relief.relief_point: Preference captured during onboarding  preference badge persistently visible in dashboard  first notification acknowledges preference ('sent via text as you requested')
tension_relief.timing: Relief arrives immediately when preference is captured (onboarding) and is reinforced with every notification (ongoing confirmation that system is honoring preference)

personalization_signals: Reference host's stated reason: 'You mentioned email overload. We'll send time-sensitive notifications via text so nothing gets missed.'
Adapt message density to host type: Busy professionals like Jessica get minimal, transactional messages. Part-time landlords might appreciate more educational content.
Display preference prominently: Dashboard header badge (' Text preferred') provides constant reassurance that system remembers and respects their choice

anti_patterns.pattern: One-size-fits-all communication: All hosts get same message frequency and channel
anti_patterns.reason: Ignores reality that different hosts have different communication constraints. Busy professionals experience default email as anxiety-inducing overload. Emotional response: 'They don't respect my time.'
anti_patterns.example_bad: [Host sets text preference but receives all notifications via email anyway] 'We send all our communications via email for consistency.'

anti_patterns.pattern: Lengthy, chatty messages that waste time
anti_patterns.reason: Busy professionals scan messages for actionable information. Long, friendly preambles ('Hope you're having a great day!') force them to hunt for what matters, creating frustration. Emotional response: 'Get to the point.'
anti_patterns.example_bad: Hi Jessica! We hope this message finds you well! We're so excited to be working with you and we just wanted to take a moment to reach out and share some news with you today...

anti_patterns.pattern: No visibility into preference status: Host has to remember what they chose
anti_patterns.reason: If preference isn't persistently visible, host experiences ongoing anxiety: 'Did I set text preference? Is the system actually using it? Should I check settings again?' Cognitive load of remembering creates stress.
anti_patterns.example_bad: [Preference set during onboarding but never shown again. Host receives text notification and thinks: 'Did I set this? Or is it sending to both? I can't remember.']
